question: Goddamnit! You know I don't deal in snuff. How many times I hafta tell you?!
answer: Don't have a fucking coronary, Lenny.

question: Well you could've at least warned me. You know I hate the zap... when they die. It just brings down your whole day. Jeez, Tick.
answer: Sorry.

question: How'd you get the tape? Why didn't the cops put it in evidence?
answer: With all the blood I guess they didn't see the rig. Guy had it under a wig.

question: Yeah, but how'd it get to you?
answer: I got ways, Lenny, I got ways. Okay, okay... I got a deal with some a the paramedics. My guy pages me and I pick it up at the morgue. So whaddya think? This clip's gotta be worth at least a grand. Right?

question: Tick. Not to dash your hopes, but I don't deal this kind of product, you know that. I'll give you four for it, cause I've gotta cut off the last bit. And my customers want uncut.
answer: Fuck that! The last part's the best. You dry-dive six stories and blammo! Jack right into the Big Black.

question: I don't deal black-jack clips! It's policy. I got ethics here.
answer: Yeah, when did that start? Come on, man! It's what people want to see, and you know it.

question: So lay it off to somebody else.
answer: Come on, Lenny. I got expenses. I got to get this rig fixed. Look at it... Give me six at least. This's a good clip, here. Gets you pumpin'.

question: Yeah, well, the first part's okay. Better than the usual soaps you bring me.
answer: Now that is cold, Lenny. I always bring you choice.

question: Sure, like this low-grade shit here, some girl in a fight with her boyfriend... it's a test-pattern. Nothing happens. I'm snorin'.
answer: Hey, you're always saying, 'Bring me real life. Bring me street life. And, like, one man's mundane and desperate existence is another man's Technicolor.'

question: I said that? Look, I'll take it for five, and you'll make out okay, because in this case it's pure cream, you don't have to cut anything back to the wearer.
answer: Ha! That's for fucking sure.

question: What else you got? Look, Jerr. I'm nothing if not a man of my word. I'll drop the money by tomorrow, next day latest. It's a little crazed right now. Yeah, on my mother's eyes, I swear. Thanks, buddy. Prick. What kinda move you call that?! Lemmings.
answer: So Dan, are you looking forward to the New Year? You're a glass-is-half-empty kind of guy, aren't you Dan? Well I for one happen to think that us making it 2000 years is worth celebrating--

question: Jimbo. I'm there, Jimmy. Right now, can't you hear me knockin'? -- so you line up the talent, shoot the clip, get it to me by Monday. OK? Client wants a guy and two girls, the guy wears... yeah, I know, thinks he's being original. Girls have to be young. So don't use your mother like you usually do. Yeah, you too, pendejo. And no big tits... French tits. That's it... like Champagne glasses... you got it. What a pro. Page me.
answer: The Last Days? You mean the coming of the Apocalypse, right? The Rapture?

question: I live here.
answer: Now just so the rest of us know how much time is left, when is the Rapture supposed to hit, exactly? Is it midnight New Year's Eve? Is that midnight LA time, or Eastern Standard or what? I mean, what time zone is God in, anyway?

question: I just got something in, Bobby, you might appreciate. A 211 at a Thai joint goes south, and these three scuzzballs end up in a gun-and-run. It's a beauty, two thumbs up. Parental discretion advised. I'm talking it's the master, not some stepped-on copy. One of a kind. Yo, Skinner. The Skin Man. Red leather. Nice feminine touch. Whattya got for me? Yeah, I can use this... ... but honey you gotta move your eyes slower next time. It's too jerky.
answer: Go ahead, caller, you're on the air. 2-K? What's that DeWayne?

question: Hi, Dave, this is Lenny. Nero. Lenny Nero. That's right. Oh, is it late? Sorry. It's just that I have something that might be of interest, and since I always call you first-- Uh, huh. Well, what would be a good time? Okay, sure. Catch you then.
answer: Let me get this straight... you gonna pay me 200 bucks to put on a hair net and bang some beautiful babe. I don't know, I gotta think about this.

question: Okay, let's get you wired up. I hope this axle grease you got in your hair doesn't screw up the squid receptors.
answer: What's all this squid shit?

question: Superconducting QUantum Interference Device. SQUID. Got it? There's gonna be a test.
answer: Hey, fuck you, man.

question: Easy, Eduardo, easy. Preserve a sense of humor at all times. Okay, the receptor rig... what I'm putting on your head... sends a signal to the recorder. See we call it "being wired," but there's no wire. You gotta keep the recorder close... five, six feet away max, like in your jacket pocket by the bed or wherever you're going to close escrow, know what I mean?
answer: Yeah, right.

question: Some tips. Don't dart your eyes around. Don't look in the mirror or you'll ID yourself. OK? You got a half hour of tape, so give me some lead-in to the main event. But don't wait too long, I don't want to be going out for popcorn. And don't act natural. Don't act at all. Just forget the thing is on. Got it?
answer: No problem.

question: You know I can get you anything you want, anytime you want it, just not right now. We'll hook up at the club later. Around eleven. Yeah. Anything without an umbrella. Looks like money to me. 10 percent, Fabri, like always. Just a second. Not to be rude, Keith, but I got to ask, are you a cop?
answer: I understand. No, I'm not.

question: You understand? Attorney! Right? Am I right?
answer: That's right.

question: Tassel shoes. Entertainment law, would be my guess. Relax. I just like to guess, is all. It's my job to know people and what they want... what's behind their eyes. That's right. My second question I gotta ask, so we get our bearings here... have you ever jacket in? Have you ever wiretripped?
answer: No.

question: A virgin brain! Well we're going to start you off right. So what do you know about this? Save us some time...
answer: Just what I've read. That the technology was developed for the Feds, to replace the body wire. And now it's gone black market. So, uh, do I get the deck from you?

question: I'll set you up, get you a deck at my cost... since my thing is the software.
answer: Clips.

question: That's right. Clips. Look, I want you to know what we're talking about here. This isn't like TV only better. This is life. It's a piece of somebody's life. Pure and uncut, straight from the cerebral cortex. You're there. You're doing it, seeing it, hearing it... feeling it.
answer: What kind of things exactly?

question: Exactly anything. Whatever you want. Whoever you want to be. Fabri, get us another round, would you. You want to go skiing without leaving your den, you can. But I'm assuming a guy like you, you wanna go skiing you fly to Aspen. That's not what you're interested in here. It's about the stuff you can't have... right? The forbidden fruit. Like running into a liquor store with a .357 magnum in your hand, feeling the adrenalin pumping through your veins. Or... ... see that guy, with the drop-dead Philipino girl friend? Wouldn't you like to be that guy for twenty minutes? The right twenty minutes. I can make it happen. And you won't even tarnish your wedding ring.
answer: Sounds good.

question: I can get you what you want. You just have to talk to me. I'm your priest, your shrink, your main connection to the switchboard of souls. I'm the Magic Man, the Santa Claus of the Subconscious. You say it, you even think it, you can have it. You want a girl, you want two girls? I don't know what your thing is or what you're curious about... you want a guy? You want to be a girl... see what that feels like? You want a nun to tie you up? It's all doable.
answer: Talk to me about costs, here.

question: Listen, before we get into numbers, I want you to try a taste. I got a deck with me.
answer: What? Right Here?

question: Step into my office. You were just an eighteen year old girl taking a shower. Are you beginning to see the possibilities here?
answer: Yeah, I'm interested, but can we get someplace a little less public?

question: You nervous? Forget it. The cops have more to worry about in this city than the squid-trade, believe me-- Damnit, Max, I was with a client! You think that's funny? To mess with a man's livelihood? It's not funny!
answer: You see the look on that preppy puke's face? Fuckin' pissed in his Topsiders.

question: Okay. It was funny. But it cost me money.
answer: Come on, amigo, the world's full of marks. And nobody knows how to work 'em like you do, pal. You could sell a goddamn rat's asshole for a wedding ring! Let me buy you a drink.

question: Least you can do.
answer: Fuckin' A right I'm mad! I might kill every man in here. But first I'm buyin' my buddy here a drink. Hey O'Neal! You were right, your wife does give good head. Bobbyyyy! Tequila por favor! Double shots. Make it Tres Generaciones, huh. Nothin' but the best for my good friend Lenny, the finest cop that ever got thrown off the vice squad. Hey, nice tie.

question: Thanks, Max.
answer: D'you always have to dress like a fuckin' pimp?

question: This tie cost more than your entire wardrobe.
answer: That's not sayin' much.

question: It's the one thing that stands between me and the jungle.
answer: To the jungle! Where outa the blue some shitbird can cap you in the back of the head and ruin your whole day.

question: You were lucky, Max.
answer: Yup. So darn lucky. I wake up with a .22-short floating in my brainpan, and a cop pension I can't live off of. Good thing I wasn't any luckier. Bobby! Another shooter right here! You seen Faith lately?

question: Naw. She won't call me.
answer: Just as well, Lenny. You gotta get past it. I mean sure, Faith was by far the most outstanding woman a guy like you could ever hope to get, I mean it's completely and deeply humiliating that she's gone, but it's over, campadre.

question: Thanks, Max. I'm touched by your concern.
answer: I just hate to see you pining away. It makes me want to vomit, frankly. Broken hearts are for assholes.

question: Lenny, I got to talk to you, it's serious...
answer: What happened, honey, some john get rough on you?

question: I mean talk private. Please, I'm in trouble, and so is Faith.
answer: There it is, the magic fuckin' word.

question: Thanks for giving me a ride. I just have a few stops, mostly on the west side--
answer: Whoa, whoa, whoa. I said I'd drop you home, but I'm not taking you on your sleazoid rounds. I've already pulled twelve hours today.

question: Come on, Mace. This is gonna be a big night. Can't you feel it? The energy in the air? There's money to be made, dreams to sell.
answer: Sleaze to peddle.

question: Just a couple of hours. It'll be fun--
answer: Excuse me. What part of NO don't you understand?

question: Mace, you're my friend. I need you. Plus I'll give you 25% of what I make tonight.
answer: Lenny, this may be a hard concept for you, but friends don't have to pay their friends. Jeez, you're pathetic. Okay, I got a pickup at the St. James. I'll take you there, you can get a cab.

question: Mace! You're a life-saver.
answer: Driving Mr. Lenny. So, what's up with you? Another busy night selling porno to wireheads?

question: No, wrong... I sell experiences. Sex is only part of it.
answer: Buncha techno-perv jerkoffs.

question: Way I look at it, I actually perform a humanitarian service. I save lives.
answer: Uh huh, I wanna hear this part.

question: Okay, take some executive... bored with his life, bored with his wife... he picks up a hooker or some girl at a bar. Then he goes around for months, torn up worrying that he's got AIDS, that he'll infect his wife. And maybe he really does catch something--
answer: Price he pays for being a scumsucking pig.

question: Everybody needs to take a walk to the dark end of the street sometime, it's what we are. But now the risks are outa line. The streets are a war zone. And sex can kill you. So you slip on the trodes, you get what you need and it keeps you from jumping your tracks.
answer: Lenny, this shit's illegal.

question: Define illegal.
answer: Me bailing your sorry pale ass out of jail twice in the last six months.

question: Yeah, but that was for love.
answer: Define love. Dammit, Lenny, you made me late.

question: What's his name?
answer: Fumitsu.

question: Mr. Fumitsu, good evening sir, Leonard Nero, Security Express. Lornette Mason here is just completing our routine driver evaluation. We do it to make sure that out VIP clients, such as yourself, are always treated as honored guests. I just need to ride up front and take some notes, if you don't mind.
answer: Um, excuse me. Sir. Excuse me. Mr. Nero. What the fuck are you doing?

question: Coming with you.
answer: You will not live to see the morning.

question: Nero.
answer: Strickland.

question: Commissioner Strickland.
answer: Sure. Whatever. See, since you shitcanned my career, I don't even have to call you sir. One of life's small pleasures.

question: Aren't you peddling your wares a little far from your usual gutter?
answer: I was invited here by a close friend, Mr. Fumitsu, see he's right over there.

question: I don't like disappointments, Nero. And do you know what disappoints me very much?
answer: Your sex life?

question: Let's talk in the car.
answer: I feel like you're turning me into a

question: I just want to see what we're like together through your eyes.
answer: I don't feel anything. Is it on?

question: Forget it's there.
answer: Make me forget it, baby.

question: Hey, careful on the jacket. This is Armani. You angry?
answer: I've had enough of this shit. You're on foot, Lenny.

question: In LA? Are you crazy? Can I come in please? I'm having a hard time hearing the stereo. I need my case. It's still in the back.
answer: Get it.

question: Listen, can we talk a little bit here, like two rational adults? That would be no.
answer: I've had it. No more wirehead shit in my car. You understand? You want to poach your lobes, do it somewhere else.

question: Okay, you got my attention, but this is cutting off the circulation to my head, here. D'you mind? I thought we were friends.
answer: No, see a friend is more than one person constantly doing favors for another. You just suck people along with your schemes and your scams and your slick act. Well I'm out. I got a kid, I got rent, I got an ex- husband someplace who doesn't send me a dime of support... I'm just trying to hold on here.

question: So am I. Just trying to get by.
answer: No, you're just trying to get off.

question: Macey... I've never seen you like this.
answer: Lenny, you're turning into some kinda squid-head low-life. You're always broke, you just go from one score to the next. And you're getting strung out... you don't even see it. Getting high on your own supply like some crack dealer.

question: I know you wouldn't be saying all this if you didn't care about me. Thanks, Mace. Really.
answer: Look, I gotta get some sleep.

question: You still like me, don't you? We're still buddies?
answer: Yeah. I don't see a way out of it.

question: Macey, I know you're tired, but can you drop me at the Retinal Fetish? It's on your way.
answer: Jesus, Lenny.

question: Begging? Groveling? Any pathetic behavior at all? Will that help? Faith's there tonight, and I've got to talk to her.
answer: Sure, Lenny. The only thing worse than a junkie is someone in love.

question: Come on, let me buy you a drink. Let's drink and make up. Alright, I'm going to see Faith. That means you can watch me suffer. I'll be in agony, you'll feel so much better. Total and thorough payback, whatdya say? Who's the new side of beef in Tran's posse?
answer: Guy named Wade Beemer. Used to be a running back for the Rams in '96 and

question: Rams... that's football, right?
answer: Forget her.

question: She still loves me.
answer: She thinks you're a bucket of dog vomit. Trust me on this.

question: She's my destiny.
answer: Destiny? You living in a perfume commercial? She's a hard-climber that dropped you like a used tampon when she got a better ride.

question: Too bad about your guy Jeriko. Tough break.
answer: Show a little respect, Nero. The man was an important artist.

question: Yeah, important for your label. Which no doubt is why you're in mourning. Don't worry, his records'll sell out now he's dead. You'll make out.
answer: I always do.

question: Lenny the loser. Panhandler of stolen dreams.
answer: Leave him alone, Tran.

question: He's no concern of mine, as long as you don't talk to him. Don't talk to anybody. You understand? Not with everything that's going on right now.
answer: You're too goddamned paranoid.

question: So, those rascals still haven't grown back yet, huh? Present. Something I had made. Let me know what you think. Fan mail from some flounder? Hi, baby. I've missed you.
answer: I know. Lenny, if Tran finds you talking to me he'll hurt you.

question: I'm already hurting.
answer: You have to go. I mean it.

question: Yeah, OK, whatever you say. Just answer one question. Is anything wrong? Iris said you might be in trouble.
answer: You talked to Iris? When?

question: Tonight.
answer: Well I haven't seen her in months. Who knows what's going on in her head. You're really running out of excuses to come around, aren't you?

question: I know you Faith. You're afraid of something. What's going on?
answer: Let it alone, Lenny. It'll take care of itself.

question: It's Tran, isn't it? This guy is poison, Faith. Listen to me. He's got you walled in on all sides. And he uses the wire too much, he gets off on tape, not on you.
answer: That's a good one, coming from you.

question: Why don't you just split? You don't love him, anybody can see that. And to him you're just some kinda possession, like a Ferrari, something to show the other guys.
answer: He has his uses too.

question: What? He gonna record you on his label?
answer: Maybe.

question: Come on, Faith! He's just toying with you. And when he gets bored, you'll be yesterday's papers. Look, baby, I've watched you create yourself out of nothing. You're like a goddamn cruise missile, targeted on making it. And you will.
answer: Damn right.

question: It's you up on that stage, not him. You don't need him.
answer: You have to get out of here. If Tran catches you he'll... he's acting crazy. He's doing way too much playback and he's getting completely paranoid. He's such a control freak, he's even paying Max to follow me around.

question: Max Pelcher? You're kidding?
answer: Yeah, for about a month now. Lenny, just stay away from Tran, okay? And stay away from me. Stop trying to rescue me. Those days are over. I'm a big girl now. Stop trying to save me, okay, because I don't need saving... Just... give up on me.

question: Can't do it.
answer: You know one of the ways movies still have Squid beat? Because they always say "The End." You always know when it's over. It's over! Now please leave. I have to go on again in a couple of minutes. Hell.

question: Shoulda told me about your new gig, buddy.
answer: I was gonna tell ya. Hey, it's just a job. I feel like shit about it.

question: You should feel like shit.
answer: I figured, what the hell, I could take the prick's money and make sure Faith was OK at the same time. Do us both good. Right?

question: Fairly twisted logic, Max, even for you. Hey, at least you got a job! Watch her for me. Stay on her.
answer: I'm on her.

question: Can I get that?
answer: Hey Lenny, where the hell are you, I think Tran's got Beemer looking for you.

question: Thanks for the tip. I recognize you. You're Wade Beemer. Running back for the Rams, am I right? I saw you play, man. You were good. Like a fucking freight train I remember saying. So what happened, injuries or what? It's always politics. Like this thing we're in here, he's paying you to tune me up, right? But I could pay you more not to. See what I mean? I could write you a check right now-- Okay cash! Logical. Here's everything I have on me, what do you say? How about a Rolex? Just not the eyes. They oughta get some lights back there. A person could get killed slipping on those stairs. Let's go.
answer: You're some piece of work, you know that. Just calmly backstroking around in the big toilet bowl, and somehow you never let it touch you. I mean, between Vice and this so- called occupation you're in now, you must've seen it all.

question: I have crawled through the gutter... through every wrinkle in the human brain.
answer: What I'm saying. But you still come out this goofball romantic.

question: It is my sword and my shield, Macey.
answer: What's that? Present from Faith?

question: No idea. It's a test pattern so far. Alright, a little B&E action. Hey, getting good. Solid suspense build.
answer: What is it?

question: Holy shit. He's jacking her in to his own output. She's seeing what he's seeing. She's seeing herself. On my God. Oh my God.
answer: My God, Lenny. What is it?

question: Black. Jack.
answer: Blackjack? I don't understand--

question: Snuff clip. It was Iris. She said she needed my help and I... aw Jesus, Mace... the sick fucker killed her.
answer: Are you sure it's real?

question: You alright? Y'okay?
answer: Yeah. No, not really.

question: Let's work it.
answer: Not now... I don't want to think about it--

question: Come on, Lenny. You used to be good at this stuff. Play it down. What's the perp doing?
answer: He stalks her. He rapes her. Then he does her...

question: And he records it. Thrill kill. Wants to see it again. And again.
answer: He records himself raping and killing her--

question: But at the same time he's sending the signal to her--
answer: So she feels... what he feels... while he's in her. The thrill while he's killing her... is sent to her, heightening her fear... which in turn heightens the turn on for him. I've seen a lot, Max.

question: So've I. Too much.
answer: But this is a bad one.

question: Top ten.
answer: He makes her see her own death, feeds off the reaction... killer and victim merging... orgasm and agony merging. And he records it all.

question: You're crazier than I thought, Lenny. Coming here... Tran's just in there.
answer: Iris is dead. She was murdered.

question: Who did it?
answer: Don't know. But this guy's real damaged goods. Iris knew someone was after her... and she said you were in danger too. Now no more games, Faith. Whatever you're hiding, whatever's going on, you have to get out of here now. Come with me right now. Don't even think about it.

question: Then what? Then what, Lenny?! You going to protect me? Big tough guy. You're a talker, Lenny. You don't even have a gun.
answer: I have a gun. It's under my bed.

question: You don't know what you're fucking with here.
answer: Tell me.

question: A tragic story, no doubt. How'd you get up here?
answer: Charm.

question: Uh huh. Look, Nero. I'll make you an offer. Take her. Right now. If she wants to go, if she's unhappy here, she can go. I'll let her choose. Faith always knows what she wants. Hands off. See?
answer: It's alright. He means it.

question: I do mean it. And I mean this... if Faith stays you go away and never come back. You scuttle back into your cockroach hole and never cross my vision again. You understand?
answer: I made my choice, Lenny.

question: You're going down.
answer: I don't love you, Lenny. Give up. You said you were going to get her out of this.

question: Maybe now you appreciate the danger we're in. It was touching the way you stood by me in there. "Stand by your man". I was moved. You were very good. I don't think he even understands that you did it for him.
answer: He doesn't know what's going on. Leave him alone.

question: I'd love to. But he keeps showing up. And you keep talking to him. I can't have that-- The only time a whore should open her mouth is when she's giving head.
answer: Fuck you.

question: Listen, can we be smart here? I could make it really worth your while... I could cut you a check for 500 each... hell, make it an even grand... I'm not saying you don't land a couple shots, just go light is all I'm saying... here, take my Rolex.
answer: Safety's on. Lenny!

question: Is this great fabric or what?
answer: You ever wonder why you get beat up a lot?

question: Come on... look in the mirror. You know it's there, you're keeping your eyes off it, you bastard... SHIT! Who are you? He knows what he's doing. He's worn before... a lot.
answer: So that gives you something.

question: It gives me... I don't know... maybe two hundred people who I know wear.
answer: Don't crank the gain any more. You're gonna fry yourself.

question: I need to see more... get more detail. Something. I feel his presence, so strong...
answer: No more, Lenny.

question: Yeah. I'm ghosting pretty bad. She came to me for help. I should have read it better... I just figured, y'know... another strung- out hooker having a bad night.
answer: It's not your fault.

question: Sex killers act alone. So there's no information on the street, which is how cases get made. Cops know they'll never nail this guy the second they look at the scene. And anyway, nobody gives a shit about a dead hooker. They're roadkill. See, it's all about what they see walking in. A dead hooker, handcuffs, penetration... they'll see a trick gone wrong. Random kill. The kind you never solve.
answer: But that doesn't add, does it.

question: No it doesn't.
answer: Because Iris knew somebody was after her.

question: She said "If they get me". They. Which means the whole sex-killer thing is a cover, which means somebody whacked her for a reason.
answer: So the guy's not a sicko.

question: If he could do what's on that tape, he's a sicko.
answer: Okay, so he's a freak who thinks he's sane pretending to be a freak. The point is, he was a hitter. Somebody wanted to shut her up. But why not just put a little lead in her ear?

question: Because it had to look random. Not connected to anything or anyone. But then why give the rape to me?
answer: That's where it gets a little strange.

question: And what about the guy that was following me?
answer: Now you're really getting paranoid.

question: The question is not whether I am paranoid, but whether I am paranoid enough. You want to rub my neck?
answer: Sure.

question: How's Zander?
answer: OK. He asks about you all the time. It's been weeks since you've seen him. I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier. I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway. I'm sorry.

question: Where were you Mom? Did you meet a guy?
answer: Just Lenny.

question: Right. That explains it.
answer: Are you going to make me beg? What is that?

question: Cheerios and wieners. I made it myself. It's good.
answer: Well give me some then... I'm starving.

question: Hey, the last day of the world and you spend it in bed.
answer: W'sup, Max?

question: Not a whole hell of a lot. They've just been saying words over Jeriko. Tensions running pretty high down here. I'm telling you.
answer: Faith OK?

question: Yeah. She's leaving with Tran so I got to boogie. Real quick... Iris checked into the Sheraton last night under a false name. Paid cash.
answer: Looks like she was holding out.

question: Yup. Hey, so I heard you dropped in on Tran last night. Another slick Lenny move.
answer: He's in this somehow... I don't know how. Just stay close to Faith.

question: Where we going?
answer: Anywhere. We'll talk about it in the car. Hand me that box of tapes, will you?

question: What is it?
answer: This tie doesn't go with blue!

question: Will you relax. There's nobody back there.
answer: Mace, the guy had a knife. To my throat. In my living room. Relaxing might be right out, okay?!

question: You better keep a low profile for a while.
answer: No shit. You got someplace in mind?

question: No, I mean the killer's got some kind of distortion in his visual cortex. The color and gray-scale values are all messed up, like color blindness. Lookit, you see the peak period ratios there? Could be some kind of tumor or brain lesion or something. Some kind of trauma This is not good. I don't like this at all...
answer: What?

question: Well, it's cutting awful close to me. I mean she was just here.
answer: Who was just here?

question: Iris, man. Pay attention.
answer: Wait, wait... wait a minute. Iris was here?!

question: Yeah, she came by last night. Shaking like a junkie, wanting me to make a copy of some clip.
answer: What clip? What was it?

question: I don't know, man, she wouldn't let me see it. Said I wouldn't want to see it. She said she was going to give it to you to hold for her. Like insurance or somethin'
answer: She never gave me a tape.

question: She never gave me a tape.
answer: Think back about what she said. Exactly what she said.

question: She wanted to go out to my car, something about my car...
answer: Something in your car...

question: That's a handy little attitude adjuster. Damn. I'm boxed in.
answer: What's it say?

question: Oh no, we're not being followed, Lenny, Don't be so paranoid, Lenny. Shit!
answer: Take it easy. The glass is bullet resistant.

question: Bullet resistant? Whatever happened to bullet proof?
answer: Lenny. Calm down. This is what I do.

question: Goddamnit!! 911 is busy!
answer: It's okay, Lenny They'd never get here in time anyway. This is bad.

question: The gas tank's going to go any second! Are you out of your fucking mind?!
answer: Fire's out, isn't it? Get in here. Come on Lenny, move it. MOVE!! Get ready to hold your breath. Lenny, kick out hard, then just follow me. Okay?

question: I can't believe we had to give them the damn tape.
answer: Yeah, me neither. It was one of my favorites. Me and Faith in a hot tub on my birthday. I'm going to really miss it. Are we impressed yet?

question: Hey Curtis? Just drive.
answer: Those two guys were cops.

question: You sure?
answer: It's the walk. Something. Anyway, they'll run your plates and get your address. We gotta keep moving.

question: Come on Zander. You can ride on my shoulders. Here you go.
answer: Cecile, get in the car. Now. He's with me. Tell me.

question: I can't tell you. You've got to see.
answer: Uh unh. I won't do it.

question: We got to make another copy of this. Little life insurance.
answer: You know what this tape could do if it gets out.

question: I've got a good idea, yeah.
answer: People finding out... seeing... that the LAPD just flat out executed Jeriko One. Jesus. Maybe they ought to see.

question: Maybe. But tonight is probably not the best night. Come on, we're rollin'.
answer: Listen to me, little sister. There's something going on, and it's very big. Now you've got to take care of Zander. And stay off the streets tonight... you hear me on this? Curtis. What about you? Do we understand each other? You stay put.

question: So, let's see, I've got Tran's goons, some squidhead psycho and the LAPD all trying to kill me. Happy new year, Lenny.
answer: Well, look at the plus side.

question: There's a plus side?
answer: Yeah. You gave up your hot tub tape to save me. That's real progress for you.

question: It was a tough call.
answer: I still can't square the psycho smarts of whoever did Iris with those two cops.

question: I don't think those cops did Iris. I think whoever Iris was wearing for killed her.
answer: Why?

question: To break the trail. If those cops had gotten hold of her, they would have beat it out of her who she was wearing for, and then gone after them too. Our killer is running as scared as we are. Which makes him really dangerous. Judging by how scared I am.
answer: Sounds like Tick's already celebrating.

question: You may be a little overdressed for this party. Yo, Tick! It's Lenny. Open up! Tick, I got to talk to you, man... oh shit. He's been cooked-off
answer: Is he dead?

question: There's more to this whole thing than you think.
answer: Whattya mean?

question: All I'm saying... you don't know how high up the food chain this thing goes. I've heard stuff.
answer: What stuff?

question: Smoke. Rumors. I've heard stuff about a death squad. A group a guys loyal to the hardline school. Guys that've had too many years of city hall and the review boards and the goddamn media pissing down their necks, suspending cops right and left, tying their hands... while outa the other side a their mouths these same people're squealing save us, save us, do something you fucking morons, crime is totally out of control.
answer: Jesus.

question: Yeah. So don't walk near me in public, alright.
answer: Thanks, buddy. See... things weren't bad enough. They weren't fucking bad enough!

question: Listen to me, Lenny... stay away from cops. All cops. You have no way of knowing who you can trust.
answer: So you're saying we just pretend is didn't happen? It happened! The LAPD executed one of the most important black men in America! Who the fuck are you to bury this?!

question: Fine. Do you want blood running waist deep in the storm drains? The gangbangers'll spread like a wave through this city and burn it to the ground. And when the fires start the street cops'll be capping off at anything that moves. It'll be all- out war and you know it.
answer: Yeah, well maybe it's time for a war!

question: Hey, Max, Mace... whoa... time out. Whoever killed Iris did Tick. It's the same sick wirehead shit. Same reason... to burn the trail. If Faith knows anything about this, and I think she does, then she's on the list. So... who's driving?
answer: Lenny! Jesus! You scared the Hell out of me. What's going on?

question: Faith, we know about Jeriko. Iris made me a copy of the tape.
answer: Oh God, Lenny. I was trying to keep you out of this.

question: How did it happen? What was Iris doing riding around with Jeriko wearing a wire?
answer: We should talk alone.

question: The scandal would wipe him out. If it got out that he had his own artists under surveillance... he'd lose all his other acts. He'd be over. So finally he gives Iris some cash and tells her to check into the hotel under a wrong name till he figures out what to do.
answer: Yeah... he figured out what to do all right.

question: You think Tran killed her?
answer: The killer knew right where she was. Because he put her there.

question: Owww!! Take it easy. Uh huh. So where are they now?
answer: He's got her up in the room, under guard. And he's still working the party... acting smooth like nothin's nothin'. So buddy... I say we work a trade.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Give him the tape. See? It's fucking brilliant! The tape for Faith. I know he'll go for it. I can set it up.

question: This is what we laughingly refer to as a plan, right?
answer: Come on! If he gives us any shit, we kill 'em all. Whattya say? Just get your butt down here. If I'm not at the shindig downstairs go to the room. It's 2203. You writin'?

question: 2-2-0-3. Got it. Stay on her.
answer: I intend to.

question: Okay, we gotta get over there. Can you borrow a dress from Cecile or something--
answer: I'm not going.

question: Whatya mean? We're going! Tran's gonna do her right there unless--
answer: Lenny... shutup. Just park your mouth and listen. It's a set-up. Think about it! Why's he been sending you tapes? To freak you, get you to rush in without thinking. Then they put one in you, put one in her, put the gun in your hand... crime of passion. This guy's bent enough to think of that.

question: That sounds right. I'm going.
answer: You gonna get yourself killed for this? This toxic-waste bitch!

question: What the fuck are you doing?!
answer: Lenny! This is your life, Lenny! Right here. Right now. This is realtime... not playback. Real... time. Time to get real. Understand what I'm saying... she doesn't love you. Maybe she did once, I don't know, but she doesn't now. These are used emotions. It's time to trade them in. Lenny, memories were meant to fade. They're designed that way for a reason.

question: Have you ever been in love with somebody who didn't return that love?
answer: Yeah. Lenny. I have.

question: It didn't stop you from loving them. Right? Or understanding them, or being able to forgive them...
answer: I guess.

question: And it didn't stop you from wanting to protect them. Did it?
answer: No. It didn't.

question: I worked Vice, Narcotics... Violent Crimes... and I saw every known depravity. I was lost, Mace. In outer darkness. Then I busted this strung-out little teeny-hooker. When I met Faith she was just another runaway giving twenty dollar blowjobs to buy crank. Another lost soul.
answer: You never told me.

question: But she was different. There was a light in her eyes... and she had this voice. It was scary, all that pain coming out of that little body. Like she could take all the hurt and rage of the entire world and lift it up to heaven in one voice. I helped her. And I promised her that I'd always be there... to protect her. See? It's not about what's in her head. It's what's in mine. I can't let go of the promise. It's... like... it's all I have left.
answer: No, it's not. Come on, Lenny. Let's go to a party. That's it. Let's bail.

question: Mace... you're a girl.
answer: Good, Lenny. I can see why the detective gig didn't work out. Come on.

question: Got your ticket?
answer: No. They must have sent it to my beach house by mistake.

question: You see Tran?
answer: Uh unh.

question: Come on, Max. Come on, buddy... Damnit. Alright. We're going up.
answer: And do what? Take on his whole posse?

question: I still got one ace to play. Tran's got what I want... and I've got what he wants...
answer: That's the original. There are no copies.

question: Exactly. That's why it's a make- able deal.
answer: Look. That tape is a lightning bolt from God. It's worth more than you, more than me, more than Faith. You understand? It can change things. Things that need changing before we all go off the end of the road. And you do not have the right to use it for currency. You go... you go alone. This is where I draw the line. I care about you Lenny... a lot more than you know... which makes us both pretty stupid. But you pawn that tape, you mean nothing to me. Ah, hell. Lenny--

question: See that guy? The one with the ramrod up his ass. That's Strickland. Take it to him.
answer: A cop? You want me to trust a cop?!

question: No. Trust me.
answer: Oh boy. What if you're wrong?

question: Then we'll be right where we are now.
answer: Yeah, right. Fucked.

question: Yeah, right. Fucked.
answer: Yes?

question: There's a tape in there you need to see. I mean right now.
answer: If it wasn't New Year's Eve, I'd arrest you for possession of illegal equipment--

question: This piece of puke hired me to kill you, baby. Do you believe that? Isn't that right, Tran? You pinhead.
answer: Oh my God. I don't believe this is happening.

question: Believe it. Now bring me the trodes, baby. Come on, quick.
answer: What're you going to do? You can't just... kill him.

question: I'm not. Just a little poach job.
answer: Jesus.

question: Hey, he was going to kill you. And this ratfuck paid to have Iris killed, to save his own sorry ass. You shut the fuck up, right now, I'm gonna pull this fuckin' trigger! Look, baby, it's now of never... the guy is a known input junkie, so a little OD won't surprise anybody. It's the only way we can be together. You know it's true.
answer: My God.

question: Here's how much I love you, baby. Don't make any assumptions about our friendship, Lenny.
answer: No. I suppose not. I didn't know you were colorblind, Max.

question: Only way I could stand your ties. I'll have that. Glock 22. Nice.
answer: Where's Faith?

question: I sent her to the party. I figured I'd wait up here until you killed Tran.
answer: What makes you think I'm gonna kill Tran?

question: You just did.
answer: Jesus!

question: You know, statistically that's the second most common word people say right before they die. Shit being number one.
answer: So... I killed Tran. Then you ran in, being on his payroll, and shot me.

question: That's pretty much the way it happened.
answer: Wait a minute. Now I'm remembering. I killed Iris too, didn't I?

question: That's right. They'll find the original of her snuff clip in your apartment. The one I left for you at the club was a copy.
answer: Was I a really busy guy? Did I do Tick too?

question: You bet. Did you like it?
answer: So why Max... why d'ya have to do Iris? She never hurt anybody.

question: Picture it... I feel like I gotta share this with somebody. It's too perfect.
answer: I won't say anything.

question: I know. So, I'm working for this puke, right? And he says he'll pay me quite large to do the hooker. But also I gotta do his bitch girlfriend cause she knows the whole score and she's totally out of control. Only he doesn't know about me and Faith. So I say to myself, if I turn the job down, he just gets somebody else. And I lose Faith... to coin a phrase. So to buy time, I do the skank. I still gotta do something about Tran... I figure it's him or me... but I can't cap him without a chump to take the fall. And who better than his girlfriend's loser ex-boyfriend... a known criminal... who has been seen hassling them in public numerous times.
answer: And who was, regrettably, also your best fucking friend.

question: No plan is perfect, Lenny. Hey, cheer up. World's gonna end in ten minutes anyway.
answer: You must be so pleased, I followed your jellybean trail right here, like a good little chump.

question: You got froggy on me a couple times. I thought that riff about the Death Squad was pretty good. I hadda keep you from bringing the cops into it.
answer: So there never was a death squad.

question: Naawww.
answer: Just those two loose-cannon cops running around covering their butts.

question: Yeah. Pretty zany, huh? All this shit caused by a random traffic stop. Hey... nothing means nothing. You know that. Look around... the whole planet's in total chaos. You gotta take what you can, while you can. Cause some shitbird can come up and put a fuckin' .22 in the back a your head any second.
answer: How did you hook up with Faith?

question: This dink hires me a month ago to eyeball her, right? But Faith knows me from you, right, so she comes up to me and says, 'Hey Max why you following me?' I say, 'I'll buy you a drink and explain.' And she says...
answer: 'So, do you enjoy watching me?'

question: You were supposed to go downstairs, baby.
answer: I know. I don't always do exactly what I'm told. So I said, 'Do you enjoy watching me?' And you said -- come on Max.

question: I said, 'Yeah. I'd even do it for free.'
answer: Uh huh. And I said, 'That's good, because I like the feeling of someone watching me. I acquired the taste from Lenny.'

question: And then she said, 'Since we're going to be spending so much time together--'
answer: 'We might as well make the best of it.'
